The work that's been going on by the HBOS team and then working jointly with the Lloyds TSB team since the 16th of January when completion took place has left us with a high degree of comfort that the balance sheet at the end of December has got the right amount of provisions in it.
Okay, thanks.
Yeah, hi there. Ladies first, yeah.

Following up from Tom's questions on the risk-weighted asset growth in 2009, just putting it in a different way, how much of the low teens growth do you expect to come from say your 139 billion treasuries portfolios, how much is from the rating migrations versus how much is from the underlying loans?

We haven't provided any further breakdown in guidance on where the growth is going to come from. I would just remind you, I think I mentioned in my voice over that there's a fair degree of pro-cyclicality still to come through in 2009, and that is incorporated within that low teens guidance on risk-weighted assets, but I haven't broken it down by portfolio.
Okay. So essentially anything that was, say, AAA at the end of 2008 in your forecast would you be still assuming to be a AAA rated asset at the end of 2009?

No, no, not necessarily. That's not what I said. I'm not giving any particular guidance on any particular asset class or its credit rating or whatever. We have proven ourselves to be very effective at managing our risk-weighted asset growth in both the Lloyds side during 2009, and actually within the HBOS franchise as well, although the drivers behind risk-weighted asset management were clearly different in the two organizations.

Good morning, this is Simon Willis from NCB. Just one quick question if I could. You've, very helpfully I think, given us some planning estimates from back in the autumn on GDP growth, and you've also helpfully given us your outlook for the housing market for this year, whilst not giving us the guidance that you gave us previously on the impact on impairments. But could I ask what your current planning assumption is for unemployment in the UK given the relevance to not just the mortgage book, but also the cards and unsecured personal book?
Thank you, Chairman. We're expecting unemployment to rise throughout 2009 and finally peak out in 2010. We haven't given specific guidance on it.
Thank you.
Other questions? Down in the third row.

Jeremy Hosking from Marathon. What is the near term 2009 outlook for issuing new shares and can you give us some feeling of how the Board is currently thinking about equity issuance at the current time? Thank you.
Thank you. We have no current plans.
Gentleman behind there. Thanks.

Hi, it's Steve Hain from Morgan Stanley. I'm sorry just touching again on the mortgage book, I mean you are the UK's largest mortgage lender and looking at the statistics on as you say slide 27, it is quite shocking. I know we keep talking about the amounts over 100%. But if we take the amounts over 80% loan to value, I mean more than 40% of your prime book, more than 50% of the buy-to-let, more than 60% of the specialist book is over 80% LTVs. And on your own assumptions of house prices falling 15% and all the features indication down maybe 20%, I mean being the UK's largest mortgage lender with that book with cover that's 13% in Lloyds and 18% in HBOS and I admire the fact that you've increased that. But I'm wondering whether that changes your thinking about probability default and loss given default as we move through '09.

I think – Steven thanks for the question. I think in looking at the mortgage portfolio, I think it's very important to remember the types of criteria that would have been taken into account when original loan was advanced. And clearly an LTV ratio is something that we talk about and most banks talk about and report and analyze publicly. But remember also that the Lloyds book in particular across the prime and the buy-to-let book has actually built up some very, very prudent lending criteria. But don't just look at LTV, but also look at income multiples and affordability.

And we've got a track record of being exceedingly responsible lender. And therefore, we would – there is a degree therefore of comfort irrespective of where a loan to value goes about the Englishman's home is his castle, he won't want to give it up unless he absolutely really has to. And that's why in response to the earlier question, I actually said that one of the key things here is unemployment, rather than particularly just focusing on loan to values and therefore surmising that there's a bigger issue than might actually be.
Okay, is that it? Thank you all very much indeed for the time and for your questions. Thank you.
